Projection¶

class pybird.Projection(kout, Om_AP, z_AP, nbinsmu=200, Qll=None, k_or=None, kp_or=None, binning=False, fibcol=False, co=<pybird.Common object>)¶

A class to apply projection effects: - Alcock-Pascynski (AP) effect - Window functions (survey masks) - k-binning or interpolation over the data k-array - Fiber collision corrections

AP(bird=None, q=None)¶

Apply the AP effect to the bird power spectrum Credit: Jerome Gleyzes

Window(bird)¶

Apply the survey window function to the bird power spectrum

dPcorr(kout, kPS, PS, many=False, ktrust=0.25, fs=0.6, Dfc=0.6344990408735429)¶

Compute the correlated contribution of fiber collisions

kPS : a cbird wavenumber output, typically a (39,) np array PS : a cbird power spectrum output, typically a (3, 39) np array ktrust : a UV cutoff fs : fraction of the survey affected by fiber collisions Dfc : angular distance of the fiber channel Dfc(z = 0.55) = 0.43Mpc

Credit: Thomas Colas

dPuncorr(kout, fs=0.6, Dfc=0.6344990408735429)¶

Compute the uncorrelated contribution of fiber collisions

kPS : a cbird wavenumber output, typically a (39,) np array fs : fraction of the survey affected by fiber collisions Dfc : angular distance of the fiber channel Dfc(z = 0.55) = 0.43Mpc

Credit: Thomas Colas

Apply window effective method correction to fiber collisions to the bird power spectrum

AP integration Credit: Jerome Gleyzes

Create the bins of the data k’s

loadWindow(kout, Qll, setk_or, setkp_or, withmask=True, windowk=0.05)¶

Pre-load the window function to apply to the power spectrum by convolution in Fourier space Qll is an array of shape l,l’,k’,k where so that $$P_l(k) = int dk’ sum_l’ Q_{l l’}(k’,k) P_l’(k’)$$ The original k on which Qll is evaluated is given by setk_or and k’ by setkp_or.

withmask: whether to only do the convolution over a small range around k windowk: the size of said range
